fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A regular category \mathcal { C } is said to be coherent if each \mathsf { Sub } (B) has finite unions and each f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B) preserves them. A coherent functor between coherent categories is a regular functor which preserves finite unions.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).
Products and coproducts in \mathsf { Sub } (A) are called intersections and unions respectively.

A coherent category \mathcal { C } is a Heyting category if for every morphism f \colon A \to B of \mathcal { C }, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f \colon A \to B and any subobject m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A, F \forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf { Sub } (FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be subobjects of A in a coherent category such that A_{1} \cap A_{2} \cong 0. Then A_{1} \cup A_{2} \cong A_{1} + A_{2}. Note that every coherent category has a (strict) initial object by .
By the following diagram is a pushout.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 0, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = {A_{1}}, se = {A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, north/style = {>->,exists}, west/style = {>->,exists}, south/style = {>->}, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: But, pushouts under 0 are coproducts.
Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category. Then intersections distribute over unions, i.e., for any three subobjects A_{1}, A_{2}, and A_{3} of A, the following holds.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m \colon A_{1} \rightarrowtail A be a subobject of \mathcal { C }. Then by , A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) can be described as the composite \mathsf { Sub } (A) \xrightarrow { m ^{*} } \mathsf { Sub } (A_{1}) \xrightarrow { \exists _{m} } \mathsf { Sub } (A). Thus, we have

fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} A_{1} \cap (A_{2} \cup A_{3}) & \cong \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2} \cup A_{3}) && \text {$ m ^{*} $ preserves finite unions} \\ & \cong \exists _{m}( m ^{*} (A_{2}) \cup m ^{*} (A_{3})) && \text {left adjoint preserves finite unions} \\ & \cong \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2}) \cup \exists _{m} m ^{*} (A_{3}) \\ & \cong (A_{1} \cap A_{2}) \cup (A_{1} \cap A_{3}) \end {align*}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A coherent category is said to be positive if it has disjoint finite coproducts.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Union as a pushout of intersection

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category and A_{1} and A_{2} be subobjects of A. Then the following square is both a pullback and a pushout in \mathcal { C }.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1} \cap A_{2}}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = {A_{1}}, se = {A_{1} \cup A_{2}}, north = {i_{2}}, north/style = {>->}, west = {i_{1}}, west/style = {>->}, south = {u_{1}}, south/style = {>->}, east = {u_{2}}, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: where the i's and the u's are the product projections and coproduct injections in \mathsf { Sub } (A) respectively.

The diagram commutes since \mathsf { Sub } (A) is a preorder: any two morphisms A_{1} \cap A_{2} \rightrightarrows A_{1} \cup A_{2} in \mathsf { Sub } (A) are equal. Moreover, this diagram is a pullback in \mathsf { Sub } (A) as the pullback of u_{2} along u_{1} is just the largest subobject contained in both A_{1} and A_{2}, i.e., the intersection. Then since both the inclusion \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} (as a right adjoint) and the forgetful functor { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathcal { C } preserve pullbacks, the square is a pullback in \mathcal { C }.

Note that the forgetful functor { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathcal { C } preserves arbitrary colimits, but the inclusion functor does not necessarily preserve them, so the same strategy does not work for pushout.

Let f \colon A_{1} \to B and g \colon A_{2} \to B be morphisms in \mathcal { C } such that fi_{1} = gi_{2}. Consider the joint morphisms (f,u_{1}) \colon A_{1} \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) and (g,u_{2}) \colon A_{2} \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}), which are monic because u_{1} and u_{2} are. Let (m,n) \colon U \rightarrowtail B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) be the union of (f,u_{1}) and (g,u_{2}) in \mathsf { Sub } (B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2})). We show that n is an isomorphism.

The functor \exists _{ \pi _{2}} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B \times (A_{1} \cup A_{2})) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A_{1} \cup A_{2}) constructed in , as a left adjoint, preserves arbitrary unions. Let us consider the image of n:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(m, n) & \cong \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(m,n)) \\ & \cong \mathsf { Img } (n) \\ & \cong \exists _{ \pi _{2}}((f,u_{1}) \cup (g,u_{2})) \\ & \cong \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(f,u_{1}) \cup \exists _{ \pi _{2}}(g,u_{2}) \\ & \cong \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(f,u_{1})) \cup \mathsf { Img } ( \pi _{2}(g,u_{2})) \\ & \cong u_{1} \cup u_{2} \\ & \cong \mathsf {id} _{ A_{1} \cup A_{2} } \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, if n is monic then \mathsf { Img } (n) \cong n \cong \mathsf {id} _{ A_{1} \cup A_{2} }, i.e., n is the whole of A_{1} \cup A_{2}, so it is an isomorphism. Let a , b \colon V \rightrightarrows U be a pair of morphisms such that na = nb. To show that a = b, it suffices to show ma = mb since n and m are jointly monic. To this end, we show that the equalizer of ma and mb is an isomorphism.
The object U (when viewed as the maximal subobject in \mathsf { Sub } (U)) is the union of the coproduct injections \ell and k.
The pullback of \ell \cup k along a or b are the maximal subobject of V since isomorphisms are stable under pullback. Thus, we have
Since finite unions are stable under pullback in a coherent category, we also have
Now, we can decompose V as the union of 4 subobjects using .
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} V \cong V \cap V & \cong ( a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cup a ^{*} (k)) \cap ( b ^{*} ( \ell ) \cup b ^{*} (k)) \\ & \cong (( a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cup a ^{*} (k)) \cap b ^{*} ( \ell )) \cup (( a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cup a ^{*} (k)) \cap b ^{*} (k)) \\ & \cong ( a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cap b ^{*} ( \ell )) \cup ( a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cap b ^{*} (k)) \cup ( a ^{*} (k) \cap b ^{*} ( \ell )) \cup ( a ^{*} (k) \cap b ^{*} (k)) \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let e \colon E \rightarrowtail V be the equalizer of ma and mb. To show that it is an isomorphism, it suffices to show that each of the 4 subobjects is contained in e, i.e., each of the 4 subobjects equalizes ma and mb. Let \ell ', \ell '', k', and k'' be given as follows:

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1}'}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = V, se = U, north = { \ell '}, south = a, west = { a ^{*} ( \ell )}, west/style = {>->}, east = \ell , east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{1}''}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = V, se = U, north = { \ell ''}, south = b, west = { b ^{*} ( \ell )}, west/style = {>->}, east = \ell , east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{2}'}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {k'}, south = a, west = { a ^{*} (k)}, west/style = {>->}, east = k, east/style = {>->}, } \qquad \DiagramSquare { nw = {A_{2}''}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{2}}, sw = V, se = U, north = {k''}, south = b, west = { b ^{*} (k)}, west/style = {>->}, east = k, east/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First, let us consider the subobject x := a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cap b ^{*} ( \ell ). Let \pi _{1} and \pi _{2} be the product projections of x.
Note that
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} u_{1} \ell ' \pi _{1} &= n \ell \ell ' \pi _{1} \\ &= na a ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{1} && \text {since $na = nb$} \\ &= nb a ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{1} && \text {since $ a ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{1} = x = b ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{2}$} \\ &= nb b ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{2} \\ &= n \ell \ell '' \pi _{2} \\ &= u_{1} \ell '' \pi _{2} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since u_{1} is monic, \ell ' \pi _{1} = \ell '' \pi _{2}. Then
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} max &= ma a ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{1} \\ &= m \ell \ell ' \pi _{1} \\ &= m \ell \ell '' \pi _{2} \\ &= mb b ^{*} ( \ell ) \pi _{2} \\ &= mbx \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Analogously, the subobject a ^{*} (k) \cap b ^{*} (k) is also contained in e. Now, we show that y := a ^{*} ( \ell ) \cap b ^{*} (k) is contained in e. The proof for a ^{*} (k) \cap b ^{*} ( \ell ) is analogous to this one.
Let \nu _{1} and \nu _{2} be the product projections of y.
Then we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex:
egin {align*} u_{1} \ell ' 
u _{1} &= n \ell \ell ' 
u _{1} \ &= na a ^{*} ( \ell ) 
u _{1} && 	ext {since $na = nb$} \ &= nb a ^{*} ( \ell ) 
u _{1}&& 	ext {since $ a ^{*} ( \ell ) 
u _{1} = y = b ^{*} (k) 
u _{2}$} \ &= nb b ^{*} (k) 
u _{2} \ &= nkk'' 
u _{2} \ &= u_{2}k'' 
u _{2} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, \ell ' \nu _{1} and k'' \nu _{2} can be factored as follows:
This yields
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex:
egin {align*} may &= ma a ^{*} ( \ell ) 
u _{1} \ &= m \ell \ell ' 
u _{1} \ &= m \ell i_{1}z \ &= fi_{1}z && 	ext {since $fi_{i} = gi_{2}$} \ &= gi_{2}z \ &= mki_{2}z \ &= mkk'' 
u _{2} \ &= mb b ^{*} (k) 
u _{2} \ &= mby \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may now conclude that n is an isomorphism. Then f can be factored as mn ^{-1} u_{1} and g can be factored as mn ^{-1} u_{2}. It remains to show uniqueness.

Let any two factors A_{1} \cup A_{2} \rightrightarrows B be given. Consider the equalizer \epsilon of these two factors. By definition, both u_{1} and u_{2} equalize these two factors, but this means that both u_{1} and u_{2} are contained in the subobject \epsilon. Thus, \epsilon is an isomorphism, so the two factors are equal.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coherent categories have an initial object

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category. Then \mathcal { C } has a strict initial object.

We claim that the domain 0 of the least subterminal object of \mathcal { C } is the initial object. First, by , the projection map \pi _{2} \colon A \times 0 \to 0 is an isomorphism for any object A \in \mathcal { C }. Thus, the composite 0 \xrightarrow { \pi _{2} ^{-1} } A \times 0 \xrightarrow { \pi _{1} } A gives a morphism from 0 to A, proving existence. It remains to show uniqueness.
Let a , b \colon 0 \rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms. Form the equalizer of a and b.
Since the codomain of e is 0, e is an isomorphism. Thus, ae = be implies that a = b.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a coherent category and 0 \rightarrowtail 1 be the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } (1). Then any morphism f \colon A \to 0 in \mathcal { C } is an isomorphism.

By definition, the pullback of the least subterminal object along the unique morphism \mathsf {!} _{ A } \colon A \to 1 is the initial object q in \mathsf { Sub } (A). Suppose that there is a morphism f \colon A \to 0. Form the following diagram:
Since q is initial, sq = \mathsf {id} _{ 0_{A} } by uniqueness. Thus, the initial object of \mathsf { Sub } (A) is isomorphic to its terminal object, i.e., A does not have proper subobjects.

Similarly, the pullback of q along \pi _{1} is the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } (A \times A). Then s \pi _{1} corresponds to a morphism from the terminal object to the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } (A \times A).

Thus, A \times A does not have proper subobjects, so in particular, the diagonal map \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A is an isomorphism. Since \Delta is the equalizer of \pi _{1} and \pi _{2}, this implies that \pi _{1} = \pi _{2}. Thus, for any parallel pair of morphisms a , b \colon B \rightrightarrows A with codomain A, we have

Thus, \mathsf {!} _{ A } is monic. Then the morphism p means that the subterminal object \mathsf {!} _{ A } q is contained in the least subterminal object of 1, so p is an isomorphism. Then, f, as the composite of two isomorphisms, is also an isomorphism.
